70-DR-2023-900051.01
CIRCUIT COURT OF
TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
PATRICK CRADDOCK, CLERK
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
AT ALEXANDER CITY
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE MCGREGOR )
PLAINTIFF/RESPONDENT )
)
VS. ) CASE NO. DR-2023-900051.01
)
BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND )
DEFENDANT/PETITIONER )
MOTION TO SUSPEND WEEKLY DINNERS AND FOR CONTEMPT
Comes now the Plaintiff/Father, Christopher Blaine McGregor, by and through his
attorney of record, Dianne James Davis, and files this Motion to Suspend Weekly Dinners and
for Contempt and would show the Court the following:
COUNT I
1) That a show cause hearing was held on the 31st day of July, 2024, on the
Defendant’s/Mother’s Petition for Contempt and the Plaintiff’s/Father’s
Counterclaim for Contempt and the Court entered an Order on November 6, 2024,
which states as follows:
6. Weekly Family Dinners: Beginning immediately, the Parties
shall attend weekly dinners together, including the Mother, Father,
A.K., and the Parties’ minor son. These dinners shall take place
every Wednesday evening at 6:30 pm CST. These Wednesday
evening dinners shall take priority over all other events and
shall only be cancelled in case of emergency. If the Wednesday
night dinner is cancelled, the Parties shall have a “make-up”
dinner the following day.
2. Reunification Therapy: Effective immediately, Mother and
A.K. shall begin attending joint counseling/therapy sessions with
Kelly Turner, a specialist in reunification therapy. Upon the
therapist submitting her reunification report to the Court, A.K.
and Mother shall continue to see Ms. Turner, provided no
ethical conflicts exist, until Mother feels that reunification
counseling is no longer necessary.
2) That pursuant to a subsequent Order of the Court, entered on November 7, 2024,
the nightly dinners were permitted to be rescheduled to either Tuesday or
DOCUMENT 117
Thursday, if the Wednesday night dinner conflicted with one of the minor child’s
pre-scheduled activities.
3) That the minor child at issue, namely: A.K., dob: 05/24/2012, is actively
involved in school, Beta Club, cheerleading, soccer, and gymnastics.
4) That the Mother has repeatedly caused scenes during these dinners, requiring law
enforcement to be called to these “dinners”.
5) That these “dinners” have become a source of trauma for the children.
6) That the Mother’s erratic behavior are such that these times as a family unit have
resulted in hostility and conflict.
7) That the purpose of these dinners-to foster a positive family environment-is
completely thwarted by the Mother’s inability to control her emotions to the point
that it is harming the child.
Wherefore, the premises considered, the Plaintiff/Father respectfully requests that
the weekly dinners be suspended and that the Defendant/Mother be ordered to undergo
counseling prior to any further attempts at family dinners.
COUNT II
1) That in an attempt to work with the Mother, the Father has allowed her to
schedule the reunification counseling.
2) That the Father has provided the Mother with a calendar detailing the child’s
scheduled activities in an effort to accommodate her.
3) That on one occasion, the Mother informed the minor child that she would not be
allowed to cheer at the final game of the season due to a counseling session that
had been scheduled, causing this twelve (12) year old child significant distress.
The following morning, the Father received an email from the counselor
informing him that the counseling session had been cancelled. To the Father’s
information and belief, the Mother knew all along that she would be out of town
for work and had no intention of attending the counseling session well before it
had been cancelled.
4) That the Mother scheduled a counseling appointment for December 23, 2024,
requiring the Father and minor child to leave a family gathering to attend, only for
DOCUMENT 117
them to arrive and find no one at the counselor’s office. It was later discovered
that the appointment had been cancelled with the Mother full knowledge.
5) That the minor child has expressed great displeasure with the counselor, reporting
to the Father that the counselor stated “she didn’t believe the child”.
6) That the counselor has now removed herself from providing services to the
Mother and minor child in this matter.
7) That the minor child is currently attending counseling sessions with CAC services
and to the Father’s knowledge and belief, the child is benefiting from these
counseling sessions.
8) That the Father is unskilled in matters of the law and has had to hire the services
of an attorney to file this motion. The Father was caused to incur legal expenses
and requests that the Mother be ordered to pay his attorney fees.
Wherefore, the premises considered, the Plaintiff/Father respectfully requests that
this Honorable Court require the Defendant/Mother to appear and state unto the Court why she
should not be held in willful contempt for thwarting the services of reunification between the
Mother and child. The Plaintiff/Father further requests that the Defendant/Mother be ordered to
pay his attorney fees. The Plaintiff/Father requests any and all such other relief to which he may
be entitled, the premises considered.
Respectfully submitted on this the 31st day of January, 2025.
/s/Dianne James Davis
Dianne James Davis (DAV007)
Attorney for Plaintiff/Father
107 Main Street
Alexander City, Alabama 35010
(256) 392-3172
(256) 392-3578 (Facsimile)
dianne@diannedavislaw.com
DOCUMENT 117
Certificate of Service

electronic filing in the AlaCourt E-File System and/or by placing a copy of same, properly
addressed and postage paid in the U.S. Mail on this the 31st day of January, 2025.
Barbara H. Agricola
127 South 8th Street
Opelika, AL 36801 /s/Dianne James Davis
Of Counsel
